docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan is idolized by young conservatives in the House, who see him as a role model and a polished spokesman for their vision of America.

headline.seo: Running Mate Paul Ryan Is an Upbeat Budget Cutter, Eager to Joust With Democrats
headline.main: Running Mate Is an Upbeat Budget Cutter, Eager to Joust With Democrats
headline.print_headline: Running Mate Is an Upbeat Budget Cutter, Eager to Joust With Democrats

docs.lead_paragraph: Rules proposed by the I.R.S. could leave millions of people in the lower middle class uninsured and frustrate the intent of Congress, which was to expand coverage.

headline.seo: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly
headline.main: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly for Many
headline.print_headline: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly for Many

docs.abstract: Rules proposed by the Internal Revenue Service could leave millions of Americans unable to afford family health coverage offered by their employers and unqualified for subsidies provided by the Affordable Care Act; debate revolves around how to define 'affordable' under provisions of the law that are ambiguous.
docs.snippet: Rules proposed by the I.R.S. could leave millions of people in the lower middle class uninsured and frustrate the intent of Congress, which was to expand coverage.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail in his plan to reduce the nation’s debt. Tapping the architect of the House Republican budget plan changes that.

headline.seo: With Ryan, Romney Casts Spotlight on Budget Details
headline.main: Elevating Ryan, and His Budget Details
headline.print_headline: Elevating the Man, and His Budget Details

docs.abstract: News analysis explores Mitt Romney's gamble in tapping as his running mate Rep Paul D Ryan, the author of the audacious House Republican budget plan; says decision could quiet criticism over his lack of detail behind his promise to reduce the nation’s rising debt through sweeping spending cuts and tax changes; Ryan plan, which Romney endorsed during the hard-fought race for the Republican presidential nomination, would cut about $6 trillion from projected spending in the first 10 years.
docs.snippet: To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail in his plan to reduce the nation’s debt. Tapping the architect of the House Republican budget plan changes that.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate Saturday in Norfolk, Va., making a selection that will intensify the campaign debate on the size and role of government.

headline.seo: Romney Adds Ryan to the Republican Ticket
headline.main: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefront
headline.sub: Romney’s Choice for His Running Mate Shakes Up Contest
headline.print_headline: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefrunt

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney introduces Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate at a spirited rally in Norfolk, Va, bringing to his side one of the party’s young conservative leaders in a move that alters the contours of the campaign and sharpens the choice facing the voters in November; selection of Ryan, the chief architect of the Republican plan for tax and spending cuts and an advocate of reshaping the Medicare program, is an effort to reset the race with President Obama. (See also Presidential Election of 2012)
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate Saturday in Norfolk, Va., making a selection that will intensify the campaign debate on the size and role of government.

byline.contributor: Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Norfolk, Va.
byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: This veteran wishes he had lost a limb. Instead, he has to watch himself lose his mind.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column on Iraq war veteran Maj Ben Richards, who is suffering from traumatic brain injury, notes that an astonishing 45 percent of those who served in Iraq or Afghanistan are seeking compensation for injuries, in many cases psychological ones; maintains that the financial cost of these disabilities will be huge, yet it is dwarfed by the human cost.
docs.snippet: This veteran wishes he had lost a limb. Instead, he has to watch himself lose his mind.
